awd_titl_txt: RUI: Photoionization, Time Delay, Positronium Formation, and Ion Impact Studies of Fullerenes, Endofullerenes, and Atoms
awd_abstract_narration:
By shining the laser light on an atom or by colliding the atom with charged particles one can probe the atom's response to such external stimuli. These are powerful scientific methods to learn fundamental properties of materials. Using these techniques to systems more complex than atoms and of direct applied interest is therefore beneficial for the advancement of basic science and technology. The systems to be studied in the current research are Buckminster fullerenes and other larger fullerenes, including atoms/clusters caged inside these molecules, called endofullerenes. These materials hold the promise of exciting applications in areas including quantum computations, superconductivity, biomedical fields, drug delivery research, magnetic resonance imaging, and organic photovoltaics. Hence, understanding the physical and chemical structure and response properties of these systems, including the influence of the fullerene cage on the behavior of the confined species, are matters of great scientific interest. Using large scale computer simulations the program aims to investigate how electrons inside the systems collectively interacts with each other to move internally or to exit the system and how much time they spend to reach the detector. How do the structure and geometry of the system play roles in the mechanism? This will be investigated both for light and fast-ion impact. By choosing exotic antiparticles like positrons to impact on fullerenes the study of the formation of electron-positron pairs, the positronium, is a novel direction of the program.

Numerical methods to be employed to model the systems and their response are based on Density Functional Theory. These methods will also be used to calculate the intensity of the emerging electron flux from the system along a specific direction and/or in all directions. From the complex variation of the detected electron flux as a function of the laser energy or the ion-impact energy researchers will extract valuable information about the system. Furthermore, the time of flight of the electrons from the irradiated target to the detector will be computed and the variation in this flight-time as a function of laser frequency will enable further insights into the scientific processes. Following the impact of positrons, the formation of the positronium (Ps) is a vital process in nature, although no attempt of Ps formation using gas-phase fullerene systems has been made until recent research that came from this program. The science to be learned from the study of Ps formation should be universal for Ps formation from nanosystems ushering new directions of Ps spectroscopy. In general, results are expected to motivate experiments and induce collaborations with experimental groups. Students and postdoctoral researchers will be involved for excellent experience in education and opportunities to become expert researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
There are five primary outcome directions of this computational research funded by the NSF:

1)      A family of molecules comprised of each of the halogen atoms, fluorine, chlorine, bromine, and iodine, encapsulated inside a Buckminster fullerene cage of carbon atoms is modelled computationally. The interaction of a laser light, with tunable frequency, with each of these endofullerene molecules is further modelled. Details of the response properties of the molecules resulting from a) the collective behavior of the whole group of electrons, b) the mixing between atomic and fullerene electrons, and c) the relocation of an electron between the atom and the fullerene sites are comprehensively studied. This is accomplished by examining the variation in the number-count of electrons knocked out by the laser light as the laser frequency tunes. The same study has also been applied for the laser shinning on clusters of sodium atoms. The learned information significantly added to the knowledge repository from previous research outcomes of the group. 

2)      For the similar processes described above the delayed or accelerated time taken by the knocked-out electrons in traveling from the molecule to the detector is also determined. The variation of this time in attoseconds as the laser frequency tunes provided detailed information about the forces, interactions the electrons are subjected to, their time of operation, and the evolution of various internal processes. For this part, the collaboration with an experimental research group has been very successful in probing and extending scopes of nano-photonics.

3)      Positrons by having opposite electrical properties of matter-particle electrons are antimatter particles. We modelled the interaction of positrons with various fullerene molecules.  We particularly studied the dynamics of a positron to capture an electron from the fullerene forming a short-lived positron-electron binary, called the positronium. Our research found that the success in positronium formation alternates between maxima and minima as the positron impact energy varies. We showed efficient ways to measure this fundamental effect using the current available technology.

4)      We have developed a high-performance (HP) computational method to simulate the relaxation of a laser-excited fullerene and endofullerene molecule and then follow the process in real time, in femtoseconds. The study of the time evolution provides valuable information to determine the lifetime of various subevents inside the complex. This info is potentially invaluable for organic photovoltaics or photothermal medical applications. Results obtained has been encouraging and can motivate novel experiments. The computational methodology promises a broad scope of applications in our future research.

5)      HP computations are employed to study slow-electron release, caused by the electron projectile impact, from biologically relevant molecules. The detail of the ejected electron counts as a function of impact energy revealed new processes and interactions. Besides gaining fundamental knowledge, some of this information is useful for medical applications. We have further studied the interaction of negative hydrogen ions with metal surfaces having regular steps in the size of nanometers. The study will be useful to understand and learn processes needed for analyzing chemical reactions on designer surfaces important in nanotechnology.
